sn42.2:1.2: His verses at Thag 19.1 speak eloquently of the tension between the worldly and the spiritual life. | The name tālapuṭa is explained by the commentary as due to his face being the color of a fresh palmyra fruit (tāla). This, however, leaves the element puṭa (“pouch”) unexplained. Tālapuṭa is known in Jain texts as a kind of poison (Uttarādhyayana Sūtra 16, verse 13;  Triṣaṣṭiśalākāpuruṣa Caritra 1.2). Tāla can mean “yellow orpiment”, a kind of arsenic used for coloring (Thig 14.1:28.1), so tālapuṭa would mean “pouch of arsenic”. As to why someone would have such a name, the protagonist of Isibhāsiyāiṁ 10.13—a government minister (amacca) named Tetaliputta—recounts having survived tālapuṭa poisoning. His life was, it seems, a series of tragedies leading him to an elaborate series of failed suicide attempts. While his story is unlike Tālapuṭa’s, the rhetoric is curiously similar: both rely on repeated, plaintive rhetorical questions to express emotional torment; for Tālapuṭa it is “when will it be?”, for Tetaliputta “who will believe me?” I wonder whether these stories share some connection. Perhaps the similar-sounding names have become confused, or perhaps he became known for the poison he survived.
